raw_text:
Adventure tale tops awards
 
 Young book fans have voted Fergus Crane, a story about a boy who is taken on an adventure by a flying horse, the winner of two Smarties Book Prizes.
 
 Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell's book came top in the category for six- to eight-year-olds and won the award chosen by after-school club members. Sally Grindley's Spilled Water, about a Chinese girl sold as a servant, was top in vote of readers aged nine to 11. Biscuit Bear by Mini Grey took the top award in the under-five category. Winners were voted for by about 6,000 children from a shortlist picked by an adult panel.
 
 The prize, which is celebrating its 20th year, is billed as "the UK's biggest children's book award". Fergus Crane includes text by Stewart and illustrations by Riddell, who also created The Edge Chronicles together. As well as the six to eights prize, it won the 4Children Special Award voted for by after-school club members. Julia Eccleshare, chair of the adult judging panel, said children's literature had "never looked stronger" in the prize's 20 years. "This award counts because the final choice of winners is made by children, who are the toughest critics of all," she said. "This year's young judges chose the winners from an exceptionally strong and varied shortlist which showcases the very best in children's books today." Previous winners have included JK Rowling, Jacqueline Wilson and Dick King-Smith.

The prizes mark the 20th anniversary of the UK's biggest children's book award.

Prize is UK's biggest children's book award celebrating 20th year, with winners chosen by children from adult-selected shortlist.

Previous winners include JK Rowling, Jacqueline Wilson, and Dick King-Smith.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Adventure Tale Wins in UK Book Award  

The UK's biggest children's book award won't feature the usual suspects.
A six-year-old book, *Spilled Water*, won best in readers aged 9–11.
It was co-written by Sally Grindley and features illustrations by Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell, who also wrote *Edge Chronicles*.
The six- to eight-year-olds category saw *Biscuit Bear* win with its team of under-five winners chosen by a shortlist of adults after 6,000 children voted for.

A book featuring the author of *Fergus Crane*, Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell, also won the prize in both categories—six- to eight-year-olds and over eight years old—and was awarded an additional 4Children Special Award by after-school club members.
The award is celebrating its 20th year, which it calls "the UK's biggest children's book award."
The judges said children's literature has looked stronger than ever in the past 20 years, with winners including JK Rowling and Dick King-Smith.
*Fergus Crane* includes the author’s text, not just illustrations, while *Biscuit Bear* was co-written by Stewart and Riddell, as well as illustrated by them.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Adventure Tale Tops Awards received two Smarties Book Prize wins, winning the category for six to eight years old and coming top in voting by after-school club members.

The book Fergus Crane was voted for by over 6,000 children, with its text created by writer Paul Stewart and illustrator Chris Riddell, along with their Spilled Water winning first place among under-five readers, and the Smarties Special Award given to the winner's story.
The Smarties Book Prize is celebrating its 20th year and is voted on by children aged nine to 11.
The shortlisted books included JK Rowling, Jacqueline Wilson, and Dick King-Smith's winning book, Spilled Water, which was chosen for the Smarties Special Award.

The book, written by Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell and published by Allen & Unwin, also came top in the category for six-to-eight-year-olds.
It was chosen by after-school club members and received a special award given by 6,000 children from across the UK.
The prize celebrates its 20th anniversary this year, with Fergus Crane's book including contributions from both Stewart and Riddell.

The 20th anniversary Smarties Book Prize is considered the UK's largest children's book award, with this year's winners selected by approximately 6,000 children from an adult-curated shortlist.
Julia Eccleshare, chair of the adult judging panel, praised the strong and diverse list as evidence of the vibrant state of children's literature.
Notable past winners include JK Rowling, Jacqueline Wilson, and Dick King-Smith.
